On Tue, 11 Jan 2005 11:07:23 +0100, Mattias Fagerlund
<mattias@...> wrote:
> 
> Hi!
> 
> During autumn last year, there was some discussion about predicting stock
> market movements. I didn't offer any input at the time since I wasn't
> currently involved in it, but I had done stock market predictions before
> that discussion, and I'm trying it out again.
> 
> I'd like to ask what came of your experiments? What indicators did you
> find useful? Did you ever find consistent out of bounds performers? What
> fitness functions did you try out?
> 
> Finding a strategy that doubles or even quadruples your money on the
> training set it is as trivial as it is useless, unless it performs well
> out of bounds - which is much harder. And in my experience, strategies
> rarely do. Or they perform well for one out of bounds period (say 2003)
> but poorly for another (say 2004).
> 
> As for my own experiments, I don't use a list of trading data for a given
> stock, instead I input a number of running averages. For instance, I
> might
> input the following indicators (all calculated the day before the market
> day that we're predicting);
> 
> CloseRate, CloseRateAvg7, CloseRateAvg14, HighestRate, HighestRateAvg7,
> HighestRateAvg14 etc.
> 
> All values are normalized by dividing by CloseRateAvg200. Inputing price
> information for the last X days might work, but it seems extremely short
> term and volatile. I've found in previous experiments that using too many
> inputs can lead to overfitting, where the strategy simply identifies a
> number of instances in the training set where it's good to buy stock.
> Those instances are never repeated out of bounds and the strategy is
> useless.

There may be some value in using returns over the various periods,
rather than average prices. I'd also consider some form of volatility
measure - the standard deviation of the logs of the returns would be a
pretty typical value.

What is/are your output(s)? Buy/Sell? Predicted future price? Bear in
mind that a short-term prediction may lead to frequent trading, which,
unless you can deliver substantial returns will lead to commissions
and bid-offer spreads eating up your profits.

> Technical Analyzis introduces a wide range of indicators, most of which
> have worked poorly in my experiments. Possibly the simplest TA strategy
> is to buy when the short term average is higher than the long term average,
> because that indicates that the stock is moving up, and to sell on the
> opposite.

This is a valuable (and profitable) system in a trending market,
although it typically boils down to "it's going up - buy, then sell
when it stops going up". It tends to be awful in a sideways market.

Momentum and Relative strength are often useful in such markets. I
never had much luck with more "exotic" indicators (stochastic
thingies, oscillators and the like) although maybe I didn't calculate
them correctly.

Are you providing less correlated market information?Stock/sector
indices? Interest/currency rates? Economic indicators? What about less
obvious stuff: the price of oil/gold, say? The current FIFA ranking of
the national football team? The Big Mac index?
 
> I'm hoping to open up the discussion again and see if there are any new
> cool ideas floating around. The two indicators CloseRateAvg7,
> CloseRateAvg14 open up for this type of strategy.

I'm curious about seeing the effects of having the model output a
"confidence" value.  I like the idea a lot, but haven't any concrete
results to show usefulness or otherwise.

I can go on about this stuff until you're asleep - I spent  a lot of
time (and CPU days) some years back trying to evolve fixed-topology
networks for stock trading. I suspended operations due to (a) lack of
easily-available/cheap data (b) inadequacy of approach - NEAT wasn't
around (c) lack of time (d) something else I've forgotten just now.

There are definitely companies out there that have invested heavily in
AI-inspired trading strategies. DE Shaw is one, part of what is now
UBS is another.
 
> cheers,
> mattias
